facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 135 of 1951 before Supreme Court of India.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by Supreme Court of India on 21st May 1951.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 19th February 1951 of Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Allahabad in Appeal No. 136 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: the 21st of May, 1951, from the Judgment and Order dated the 19th February, 1951, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Allahabad in Appeal No. 136 of 1950.

facts.text: Dispute regarding workers' claim for bonus.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal with special leave is directed against the judgment and order of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India in a dispute regarding the workers claim for bonus.

facts.text: Appellant made profit of Rs. 11,97,648-11-9 in 1948.

anchor.surface_text: During the year 1948 the appellant made a profit of Rs. 11,97,648-11-9. It paid 24 3 per

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal agreed with Industrial Court on facts and law but awarded bonus at annas 4 per rupee on social justice grounds.

holdings.text: the claim for bonus can be made by the employees only if as a result of the joint contribution of -capital and labour the industrial concern has earned profits.

anchor.surface_text: the claim for bonus can be made by the employees only if as a result of the joint contribution of -capital and labour the industrial concern has earned profits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint contribution of capital and labour must yield profits; follows Full Bench formula in Millowners Association case.

holdings.text: If in any particular year the working of the industrial concern has resulted in loss there is no basis no justification for a demand for bonus.

anchor.surface_text: If in any particular year the working of the industrial concern has resulted in loss there is no basis no justification for a demand for bonus. Bonus is not a deferred wage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trading loss eliminates available surplus after prior charges; no profits for distribution as bonus.

holdings.text: Bonus is not a deferred wage. Because if it were so it would necessarily rank for precedence before dividends The dividends can only be paid out of profits

anchor.surface_text: Bonus is not a deferred wage. Because if it were so it would necessarily rank for precedence before dividends The dividends can only be paid out of profits

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bonus contingent on profits, not prior claim like wage; dividends only from profits.

holdings.text: The surplus that remained after meeting the aforesaid deductions would be available for distribution as bonus.

anchor.surface_text: Provision for depreciation, Reserves for rehabilitation, A return at 6 per cent. on the paid up capital. A return on the working capital at a lesser rate than the return on paid up capital. The surplus that remained after meeting the aforesaid deductions would be available for distribution as bonus.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts Full Bench formula: prior charges on gross profits before surplus for bonus.

holdings.text: The workers not being members of the company would also not have any right, title and interest in the reserves or the undistributed profits which would form part of the assets of the company.

anchor.surface_text: The workers not being members of the company would also not have any right, title and interest in the reserves or the undistributed profits which would form part of the assets of the company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Workers lack shareholder status; reserves for shareholders, not bonus claim.

holdings.text: Linking of bonus to dividend would obviously create difficulties. Because if that theory was accepted a company would not declare any dividends

anchor.surface_text: Linking of bonus to dividend would obviously create difficulties. Because if that theory was accepted a company would not declare any dividends but accumulate the profits, build up reserves

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy consequence: enables reserve building without bonus liability.

holdings.text: The considerations of social justice imported by the Labour Appellate Tribunal in arriving at the decision in favour of the respondent were not only irrelevant but untenable.

anchor.surface_text: The considerations of social justice imported by the Labour Appellate Tribunal in arriving at the decision in favour of the respondent were not only irrelevant but untenable. Social justice is a very- vague and indeterminate expression

holdings.reasoning_summary: Social justice vague; must follow solid formula like Full Bench, not override loss principle.

holdings.text: article 136 has vested in this, Court exceptional and overriding power to interfere where it reaches the conclusion that a person has been dealt with arbitrarily or that a Court or tribunal within the territory of India has not given a fair deal to a litigant.

anchor.surface_text: article 136 has vested in this, Court exceptional and overriding power to interfere where it reaches the conclusion that a person has been dealt with arbitrarily or that a Court or tribunal within the territory of India has not given a fair deal to a litigant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Bharat Bank and Dhakeswari cases; interferes due to LAT's arbitrary social justice application.

holdings.text: The result therefore is that the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal appealed against must be reversed and that of the Industrial Court Textiles and Hosiery , Kanpur, restored.

anchor.surface_text: The result therefore is that the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal appealed against must be reversed and that of the Industrial Court Textiles and Hosiery , Kanpur, restored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: LAT erred in law by awarding bonus despite loss; restores no bonus order.

Websters International Dictionary defines bonus as something given in addition to what is ordinarily received by or strictly due to the recipient . anchor.surface_text: Attorney-General v. City of Woburn 1  The word bonus is companymonly used to denote an increase in salary or wages in companytracts of employment. The offer of a bonus is the means frequently adopted to secure companytinuous service from an employee to enhance his efficiency and to augment his loyalty to his employer and the employees acceptance of the offer by performing the things called for by the offer binds employer to pay the bonus so called.

precedents.cited_proposition: Bonus denotes an increase in salary or wages; offer and acceptance bind employer to pay

But in both cases it is something in addition to or in excess of that which is ordinarily received.

anchor.surface_text: Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi v. Employees of the Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi 1 , where we held that the Industrial Tribunals were tribunals within the meaning of article 136 and further that article 136 has vested in this, Court exceptional and overriding power to interfere where it reaches the companyclusion that a person has been dealt with arbitrarily or that a Court or tribunal within the territory of India has number given a fair deal to a litigant.
